qas.question: Who coined the name "mammal" from the scientific name Mammalia?
What do all female mammals have in common when they have children?
How many mammals were known to exist up to 2006?
How many families did mammals consist of as of 2006?
What term  did IUCN coin in 1758?
In 1758 how many mammal species were known?
What was completed by Carl Linnaeus in 2006?
How was the IUCN Red List grouped?
How many accepted species are there according to Carl Linnaeus?

context: The word <b4_0>"mammal"<b4_0/> is modern, from the scientific name Mammalia coined by <a0_0>Carl Linnaeus<a0_0/> in 1758, derived from the Latin mamma ("teat, pap"). All female mammals <a1_0>nurse their young with milk<a1_0/>, which is secreted from special glands, the mammary glands. According to Mammal Species of the World, <a2_0><b5_0>5,416<b5_0/><a2_0/> species were known in 2006. These were grouped in <b7_0>1,229 genera, <a3_0>153 families<a3_0/> and 29 orders<b7_0/>. In 2008 the IUCN completed <b6_0>a five-year, 1,700-scientist Global Mammal Assessment<b6_0/> for its IUCN Red List, which counted <b8_0>5,488<b8_0/> accepted species.
